docs.title: WordNet DB Migrator
docs.text: A utility to migrate WordNet database from SQLite to PostgreSQL.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
WordNet DB Migrator is a tool designed to help you migrate a WordNet database from SQLite to PostgreSQL. It handles the entire migration process, including:

  • Extracting the schema from the SQLite database
  • Creating tables in PostgreSQL
  • Migrating data
  • Setting up indexes and foreign keys
  • Validating the migration

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Step-by-Step Migration: The migration process is divided into logical steps that can be run individually or as a complete sequence.
  • Configurable: Easily configure database connections and migration options.
  • Validation: Built-in validation to ensure data integrity after migration.
  • Detailed Logging: Comprehensive logging of the migration process.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Install the package
pip install wordnet-db-migrator

# Run the migration
wordnet-db-migrator --sqlite-path /path/to/wordnet.db

For more detailed instructions, see the Installation and Usage guides.

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
• Installation Guide: How to install WordNet DB Migrator
  • Usage Guide: How to use WordNet DB Migrator
  • Development Guide: How to contribute to WordNet DB Migrator
  • API Reference: Detailed API documentation

docs.title: API Reference
docs.text: This document provides a reference for the WordNet DB Migrator API.

docs.title: wordnet_db_migrator.config
docs.text: The configuration module handles loading and managing configuration settings.

docs.title: Config
docs.text: The main configuration class for WordNet DB Migrator.

docs.title: Methods
docs.text:
• __init__(): Initialize configuration with default values and load from files.
  • _load_config(): Load configuration from files.
  • _update_nested_dict(d, u): Update a nested dictionary with values from another dictionary.
  • _setup_paths(): Set up paths based on configuration.
  • _setup_file_logging(): Set up file logging for the application.
  • setup_console_logging(): Set up console logging if show_console_logs is True.
  • save_config(): Save current configuration to user config file.
  • prompt_credentials(): Prompt for PostgreSQL credentials.
  • ensure_pg_credentials(): Ensure PostgreSQL credentials are available, prompting if necessary.

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
• SQLITE_PATH: Get/set SQLite database path.
  • PG_HOST: Get/set PostgreSQL host.
  • PG_PORT: Get/set PostgreSQL port.
  • PG_DATABASE: Get/set PostgreSQL database name.
  • pg_user: Get/set PostgreSQL username.
  • pg_password: Get/set PostgreSQL password.
  • SHOW_DB_NAME: Get/set show database name setting.
  • SHOW_LOGGING: Get/set show logging setting.
  • MAX_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS: Get/set maximum login attempts.
  • BATCH_SIZE: Get/set batch size.
  • force_mode: Get/set force mode setting.

docs.title: wordnet_db_migrator.cli
docs.text: The command-line interface module handles command-line argument parsing and validation.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• show_help(): Display help information and exit.
  • validate_cli_args(): Validate command-line arguments.
  • parse_cli_args(all_steps): Parse command-line arguments and determine which steps to run.

docs.title: wordnet_db_migrator.main
docs.text: The main module coordinates the step-by-step process of migrating a WordNet database from SQLite to PostgreSQL.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text: • main(): Main function to coordinate the WordNet migration process.

docs.title: wordnet_db_migrator.bootstrap
docs.text: The bootstrap module handles setting up the environment for the WordNet DB Migrator application.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• setup(): Set up the environment for the WordNet DB Migrator application.
  • print_header(message): Print a header message.

docs.title: Step Modules
docs.text: Each step in the migration process is implemented as a separate module in the steps directory.

docs.title: wordnet_db_migrator.utils.db_utils
docs.text: Utility functions for database operations.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• connect_to_sqlite(db_path): Connect to a SQLite database.
  • connect_to_postgres(host, port, database, user, password): Connect to a PostgreSQL database.
  • execute_query(connection, query, params=None): Execute a query on a database connection.
  • fetch_all(connection, query, params=None): Fetch all results from a query.
  • fetch_one(connection, query, params=None): Fetch one result from a query.
  • close_connection(connection): Close a database connection.

docs.title: Development Guide
docs.text: This guide provides information for developers who want to contribute to WordNet DB Migrator or modify it for their own needs.

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
The WordNet DB Migrator project is organized as follows:

wordnet_db_migrator/
├── .github/                    # GitHub-specific files
│   ├── workflows/              # GitHub Actions workflows
│   │   └── ci.yml              # CI/CD configuration
│   └── ISSUE_TEMPLATE/         # Issue templates
├── docs/                       # Documentation
│   ├── installation.md         # Installation guide
│   ├── usage.md                # Usage guide
│   └── development.md          # Development guide (this file)
├── examples/                   # Example usage
├── tests/                      # Test cases
├── src/                        # Source directory
│   └── wordnet_db_migrator/    # Main package
│       ├── __init__.py         # Package initialization
│       ├── cli.py              # Command-line interface
│       ├── config.py           # Configuration handling
│       ├── main.py             # Main entry point
│       ├── steps/              # Individual steps
│       │   ├── __init__.py
│       │   ├── step010_test_sqlite_connection.py
│       │   ├── ...
│       └── utils/              # Utility functions
│           ├── __init__.py
│           └── db_utils.py
├── .gitignore                  # Git ignore file
├── LICENSE                     # License file
├── pyproject.toml              # Modern Python packaging
├── README.md                   # Main README
├── CONTRIBUTING.md             # Contribution guidelines
└── setup.py                    # Setup script

docs.title: Development Setup
docs.text:
To set up your development environment:

  1. Clone the repository: 

    git clone https://github.com/onareach/wordnet-db-migrator.git
cd wordnet_db_migrator

  2. Create a virtual environment: 

    python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\Scripts\activate

  3. Install development dependencies: 

    pip install -e ".[dev]"

docs.title: Adding a New Step
docs.text:
The migration process is divided into steps, each implemented as a separate module in the steps directory. To add a new step:

  1. Create a new module in the steps directory with a name following the pattern stepXXX_description.py, where XXX is a three-digit number indicating the order of the step.

  2. Implement the step as a function named run that returns a boolean indicating success or failure:

# src/wordnet_db_migrator/steps/stepXXX_description.py
"""
Step XXX: Description of the step.

This module implements step XXX of the WordNet migration process.
"""
import logging
from wordnet_db_migrator.config import config

# Set up logging
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)

def run() -> bool:
    """
    Run step XXX of the WordNet migration process.

    Returns:
        bool: True if the step was successful, False otherwise.
    """
    logger.info("Starting step XXX")

    try:
        # Implement the step here

        logger.info("Step XXX completed successfully")
        return True
    except Exception as e:
        logger.error(f"Step XXX failed: {e}")
        config.success = False
        return False
  1. Add the step to the ALL_STEPS list in main.py:
ALL_STEPS: List[StepDefinition] = [
    # ...
    ("Step XXX: Description", stepXXX_description.run),
    # ...
]

docs.title: Modifying an Existing Step
docs.text:
To modify an existing step:

  1. Locate the step module in the steps directory.
  2. Make your changes to the run function.
  3. Test your changes (see the Testing section below).

docs.title: Adding a New Command-Line Option
docs.text:
To add a new command-line option:

  1. Add the option to the VALID_FLAGS set in cli.py:
VALID_FLAGS: Set[str] = {
    # ...
    "--new-option",
    # ...
}

  1. Add the option to the help text in the show_help function in cli.py.

  2. Add code to handle the option in the validate_cli_args function in cli.py.

docs.title: Running Tests
docs.text:
Run tests with pytest:

pytest

docs.title: Writing Tests
docs.text:
Tests are located in the tests directory. To add a new test:

  1. Create a new module in the tests directory with a name following the pattern test_*.py.

  2. Implement test functions using pytest:

# tests/test_example.py
"""
Tests for the example module.
"""
import pytest
from wordnet_db_migrator import example

def test_example_function():
    """Test the example function."""
    result = example.function()
    assert result == expected_result

docs.title: Code Style
docs.text:
This project follows PEP 8 style guidelines. We use:

  • Black for code formatting
  • isort for import sorting
  • flake8 for linting
  • mypy for type checking

You can run these tools with:

black .
isort .
flake8
mypy src/wordnet_db_migrator

docs.title: Docstrings
docs.text:
All modules, classes, and functions should have docstrings following the Google style:

def function(arg1: str, arg2: int) -> bool:
    """
    Short description of the function.

    Longer description of the function if needed.

    Args:
        arg1: Description of arg1
        arg2: Description of arg2

    Returns:
        Description of the return value

    Raises:
        ValueError: Description of when this error is raised
    """
    # Function implementation

docs.title: Markdown Documentation
docs.text:
Documentation files are written in Markdown and located in the docs directory. To add a new documentation file:

  1. Create a new Markdown file in the docs directory.
  2. Add a link to the new file in the appropriate place (e.g., in the README.md or another documentation file).

docs.title: Releasing a New Version
docs.text:
To release a new version:

  1. Update the version number in src/wordnet_db_migrator/__init__.py:
__version__ = "X.Y.Z"

  1. Update the CHANGELOG.md file with the changes in the new version.

  2. Commit the changes:

git add src/wordnet_db_migrator/__init__.py CHANGELOG.md
git commit -m "Bump version to X.Y.Z"
  1. Tag the release:
git tag -a vX.Y.Z -m "Version X.Y.Z"
git push origin vX.Y.Z
  1. Build the package:
python -m build
  1. Upload to PyPI:
twine upload dist/*

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you need help with development, please:

  1. Check the documentation in the docs directory
  2. Look at the code and comments
  3. Check the GitHub Issues
  4. Create a new issue if your question is not answered elsewhere

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text: This guide provides detailed instructions for installing WordNet DB Migrator.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.6 or higher
  • PostgreSQL server (installed and running)
  • SQLite WordNet database
  • Virtual Environment: This application is designed to run in a Python virtual environment
  • psycopg2-binary: The application specifically requires the psycopg2-binary package, not the standard psycopg2 package

docs.title: Virtual Environment Setup (Important)
docs.text: WordNet DB Migrator is designed to run in a Python virtual environment. This isolates the application's dependencies from your system Python installation and prevents conflicts with other packages.

docs.title: Creating a Virtual Environment
docs.text:
# Create a virtual environment
python -m venv wordnet_db_migrator_venv

# Activate the virtual environment
# On Windows:
wordnet_db_migrator_venv\Scripts\activate
# On macOS/Linux:
source wordnet_db_migrator_venv/bin/activate

You should see the virtual environment name in your command prompt, indicating it's active. All subsequent installation commands should be run with the virtual environment activated.

docs.title: Method 1: Using pip (Recommended)
docs.text:
The easiest way to install WordNet DB Migrator is using pip within your activated virtual environment:

# Make sure your virtual environment is activated
pip install wordnet-db-migrator

This will install the latest stable version from PyPI, including all required dependencies.

docs.title: Method 2: From Source
docs.text:
To install the latest development version from source:

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/onareach/wordnet-db-migrator.git
cd wordnet-db-migrator

# Create and activate a virtual environment (if not already done)
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\Scripts\activate

# Install in development mode
pip install -e .

docs.title: Method 3: Using the Installation Script
docs.text:
If you've downloaded the source code, you can use the included installation script:

chmod +x install.sh
./install.sh

This script will: 1. Check Python version 2. Create a virtual environment 3. Install dependencies 4. Install WordNet DB Migrator in development mode

docs.title: Important Note About Dependencies
docs.text:
This project specifically requires psycopg2-binary and not the standard psycopg2 package. Using the standard psycopg2 package may cause errors. The correct dependency will be installed automatically when you install the package, but if you're installing dependencies manually, make sure to use:

pip install psycopg2-binary

docs.title: Verifying Installation
docs.text:
To verify that WordNet DB Migrator is installed correctly:

# Make sure your virtual environment is activated
wordnet-db-migrator --help

This should display the help message with available options.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Installation
docs.text:
If you encounter issues during installation:

  1. Ensure your virtual environment is activated
  2. Check that your command prompt shows the virtual environment name

  3. If not, activate it using the commands in the "Creating a Virtual Environment" section

  4. Verify psycopg2-binary is installed correctly 

    pip list | grep psycopg2

  5. You should see psycopg2-binary in the list, not just psycopg2

  6. Check Python version compatibility 

    python --version

  7. Ensure you're using Python 3.6 or higher

docs.title: Installing WordNet SQLite Database
docs.text:
WordNet DB Migrator requires a WordNet SQLite database to migrate. If you don't have one:

  1. Download the WordNet database from WordNet's official website
  2. Follow the instructions to convert it to SQLite format (if necessary)
  3. Note the path to the SQLite database file

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Now that you have installed WordNet DB Migrator, you can proceed to the Usage Guide to learn how to use it.

docs.title: Usage Guide
docs.text: This guide provides detailed instructions for using WordNet DB Migrator.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
The simplest way to use WordNet DB Migrator is:

wordnet-db-migrator --sqlite-path /path/to/wordnet.db

This will: 1. Connect to the SQLite database 2. Prompt for PostgreSQL credentials 3. Create a new PostgreSQL database 4. Migrate the schema and data 5. Validate the migration

docs.title: Command-Line Options
docs.text:
WordNet DB Migrator supports the following command-line options:

Option Description Default --help Show help message and exit - --force Skip confirmation prompts False --show_db_name Show which PostgreSQL database is being worked on in each step False --show_logging Display logging messages in the terminal False --list_steps Show a list of all available steps and exit - --select_step Manually select which step to start from - --start_step N Start from step number N 1 --end_step M End after step number M Last step --only_step N Run only step number N - --list_data_tables Show list of tables that can be inserted - --insert_data_table X Load data into just the given table -

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
WordNet DB Migrator uses a JSON configuration file located at ~/.wordnet_db_migrator/config.json. You can modify this file to set default values for various settings:

{
  "sqlite": {
    "path": "/path/to/wordnet/sqlite/database.db"
  },
  "postgres": {
    "host": "localhost",
    "port": 5432,
    "database": "wordnet"
    // Note: username and password are NOT stored
  },
  "output": {
    "directory": "./output",
    "log_level": "info",
    "show_console_logs": false,
    "show_db_name": false
  },
  "application": {
    "batch_size": 1000,
    "force_mode": false
  },
  "last_confirmed": "2025-05-08T12:00:00Z"
}

docs.title: Migration Steps
docs.text:
WordNet DB Migrator performs the migration in several steps:

  1. Test SQLite database connection
  2. Set up PostgreSQL credentials
  3. Create WordNet database in PostgreSQL
  4. Purge directories (if needed)
  5. Extract SQLite schema
  6. Analyze dependencies
  7. Extract SQLite metadata
  8. Generate table scripts
  9. Generate foreign key scripts
  10. Generate foreign key validators
  11. Generate index scripts
  12. Run table creation scripts
  13. Run index creation scripts
  14. Insert data into tables
  15. Validate foreign key data
  16. Apply foreign keys

You can run specific steps using the --only-step, --start-step, and --end-step options.

docs.title: Basic Migration
docs.text:
wordnet-db-migrator

This will use the SQLite path from the configuration file or prompt for it if not set.

docs.title: Specifying SQLite Path via Environment Variable
docs.text:
export WORDNET_SQLITE_PATH=/path/to/wordnet.db
wordnet-db-migrator

docs.title: Running Specific Steps
docs.text:
# List all steps
wordnet-db-migrator --list_steps

# Run only step 5
wordnet-db-migrator --only_step 5

# Start from step 3
wordnet-db-migrator --start_step 3

# Run steps 2 through 5
wordnet-db-migrator --start_step 2 --end_step 5

docs.title: Forcing Operations
docs.text:
wordnet-db-migrator --force

This will skip confirmation prompts, such as when dropping a database.

docs.title: Showing Database Name
docs.text:
wordnet-db-migrator --show_db_name

This will show which PostgreSQL database is being worked on in each step.

docs.title: Showing Logging Messages
docs.text:
wordnet-db-migrator --show_logging

This will display logging messages in the terminal.

docs.title: Data Management
docs.text:
# List all tables
wordnet-db-migrator --list_data_tables

# Insert data into a specific table
wordnet-db-migrator --insert_data_table synsets

docs.title: SQLite Database Not Found
docs.text:
If you see an error like:

Error: SQLite database not found: /path/to/wordnet.db

Make sure the path to your SQLite database is correct and the file exists.

docs.title: PostgreSQL Connection Failed
docs.text:
If you see an error like:

Error: Could not connect to PostgreSQL server

Make sure your PostgreSQL server is running and the credentials are correct.

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text:
If you see an error like:

Error: Permission denied when creating database

Make sure the PostgreSQL user has the necessary permissions to create databases.

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you encounter any issues not covered in this guide, please:

  1. Check the GitHub Issues to see if someone else has reported the same problem
  2. If not, create a new issue with a detailed description of the problem

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
After successfully migrating your WordNet database to PostgreSQL, you can:

  1. Connect to the PostgreSQL database using your favorite client
  2. Explore the data using SQL queries
  3. Use the database in your applications
